comments.author: Heron
comments.content: I do have pomegranate molasses in the fridge, so how much should I use? The same 2 tbsp?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hi Heron - if you want to make something like my dish, yes, 2 Tbsp would be about right. Otherwise, google Fesenjan-e Bademjan and you can see more about the traditional recipe. Thanks, Michael

comments.author: Anh
comments.content: I can't say I will ever become a vego. But this veg fish is STUNNING!

comments.author: Shannon
comments.content: This looks really interesting. I am always looking for ways to use up eggplant from our CSA. I tend to sneak it into soups, stews, and sauces since my husband's not a fan.

comments.author: alessandra@clear.net.nz
comments.content: Interesting use of mosto cotto. Just like to add, it takes a bit more than ageing to make mosto cotto into balsamic. (You need the fermentation and acetic bio- oxidation - turning the must into vinegar) before the ageing. Sorry for sounding so dotty, and please indulge me Michael, the fact is that I am from Modena.... :-) ;-)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: @Alessandra - you are so right! By the way, do you use the terms mosto cotto and saba interchangably?

comments.author: alessandra@clear.net.nz
comments.content:
Some people do, Saba is mosto cotto, grape must cooked for a few hours in a copper pot (with some whole walnuts inside - usually 12, don't know why, so that it doesn't stick to the bottom) it becomes very sweet and it is bottled as saba or sapa. To make balsamic vinegar you also cook must, in bigger pots, for about 11 hours, without walnuts :-)

I mean, there are many types of mosto cotto, and some is called saba.

FYI, Aceto Balsamico Tradizionale di Modena is made only with cooked must, while Aceto Balsamico di Modena (without the word tradizionale) is made with cooked must and wine vinegar.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Very interesting about the walnuts, that could be a hidden nut allergy risk!

comments.author: AZ
comments.content:
Hi,

Maybe I'm blind, but in the directions you don't mention when the water is added..

Thanks!

comments.author: R
comments.content: You may find it interesting to know that we Persians have another dish (called khoresht-e-bademjan or eggplant stew) which is basically eggplant cooked with some meat and tomatoes, and in that we put something we call "ghooreh" which is green (as in not ripe) grapes or the cooked juice of that "ab-ghooreh". Ghooreh is sour and I've never tried mosto cotto, but maybe it is similar to ab-ghooreh. Ab-ghooreh is also the perfect salad dressing in my opinion.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Wow, that sounds really interesting! Sounds more similar to verjus (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verjuice) than mosto cotto. We are lucky enough to live in an area where it shouldn't be hard to get unripe grapes, so I'll have to try making that myself (both cooked and uncooked). Thanks, Michael

comments.author: Mrs Ergül
comments.content: I'm very excited to try this recipe. Have everything from the pomegranate molasses to walnut and sumac!! Will definitely blog about it if it turns out good :)

comments.author: Myrsije
comments.content:
I'm trying this tonight. I don't have walnuts but I'm going to ground some sunflower seeds and use that instead. I have prepared eggplant in both ways and with my experience I have found that when you salt, rinse and dry the eggplant they roast/brown really well and keep their form ie don't become mushy. The salt brings out excess water moisture and the key is to rinse and pat dry before cooking. 

I look forward to eating this. It sounds delicious
